L.A. Noire was clearly never intended to be played on PC. Hexacore 3.0 GHz processor, 8 GB RAM and HD7850 were capable of pushing an average of 18 FPS out of this game playing at 1200p. Playing at 800x600 with all settings scaled down produced an average of 19 FPS.  Even so, I got through the half of the game, hoping that at least the story would be OK. That's when I quit. Not because the story (it was OK and probably will continue to be troughout the rest of the game), but because of the way the interviewing works. Actually, how it does not work with a common sense, and most of the time you're left on guessing or spending intuition points because there is no clear way of knowing what the right choice is.  Too many questions with no clear answers, it made me want to just click through the answers without even thinking just to progress the story. But low, almost unplayable framerate combined with interviewing nonsense - I had to let it go.  Following is a simple example of a badly constructed intervieweing and one that made me give up on the game.  *** SPOILER ALERT ***  So I'm interviewing Miss Candy WhateverHerLastNameIs and the first question I've got right.  The second one is whether she knows about the names of certain bookmakers. Her boyfriend knows about them, the man laying on the floor knows about them, but there is no way to know if she does, no evidence points to her exactly. So I go for Doubt and of course, that's wrong because the fact that her boyfriend had a paper with their names in his locker should've made me sure that she's involved.  Next, I ask her whether she knows about boyfriend's whereabouts, she said she doesn't. Now I have a bus ticket and a picture of a boat as evidence, so not wanting to fail again, I'm guessing she's going to meet him were the bus ticket leads her (because he's on the run). I say she's lying, put out the evidence and it's fail again.

I'm glad I was finally able to run this game smoothly. LA Noire is easily one of the best games I have played in the past several years. The graphics are beautifully rendered and accentuate the overall style of the game. The cornerstone of the game is the gathering of clues at crime scenes and key locations as well as it's use of interrogations that make use of the complex facial features of the character models where you have to observe the mannerisms of the person of interest to determine if they are telling the truth. The investigations are interspersed with 'action scenes' that range from car chases to shootouts and fist fights. I think some people may be turned off by this game if they assume that it plays like Rockstar's flagship Grand Theft Auto franchise - it might use a similar engine but LA Noire is definitely a different animal than GTA. Fans of crime dramas like LA Confidential and police procedurals like Dragnet should try LA Noire.

L.A. Noire is a noir detective action adventure video game developed by Team Bondi and published by Rockstar Games released as a Microsoft Windows port on 8 November 2011. It is set in Los Angeles in 1947 and tells the story of a LAPD officer solving a range of cases across five divisions.  This game draws heavily from both the plot and aesthetic elements of film noir which are stylistic films made popular in the 1940s and 1950s. Because this is a game about 1940s detective work, it doesn't shy away from adult themes such as gruesome multilations on a full frontal nudity victim, racial bigotry, paedophillia and even necrophillia. Definitely not a suitable game for the young.  Graphics wise, I am most impressed with the character face renderings which till this date (2015), no other game I have seen comes close to replicating how realistic the faces are. That said, while the faces were realistic, their body animations look rather stiff and it can look quite jarring at times.  Gameplay wise, while there is an open-world of Los Angeles for you to explore, there really isn't any point in doing so other then solving minor crimes and finding several point of interests which contributes to an achievement score. The game even allows you to completely skip driving to locations if you so wish. With a total game time of about 25 hours, it is spread over a total of 26 cases and they are all played out in a very linear fashion, not unlike a graphic adventure game.   To break down the gameplay at its basics, almost every case is basically   1) Go to Location. 2) Look for a bunch of clues. 3) Question some people.  And thats it. There are sometimes action sequences and gunfights inserted along the way to break the cycle. But thats basically it. Rinse and repeat until every case is solved. I actually recommend following a walkthrough to get the correct answers when questioning people so there is a nice flow to the story with no disruptions.  Overall Rating: 8.0 / 10 Well worth playing for its story and character development despite its very linear approach at storytelling. Don't go into this game expecting it to be a Grand Theft Auto or Mafia clone. Definitely well worth a purchase when on a sale.
honestly its homo

It's a game you must try at least once because there is nothing else like it. If you like watching detective shows like CSI then you will instantly fall in love with it. It's a unique experience I've never really had in a game like it before or since. It's a detective game in every sense of the word. You get a case, you find clues, interrogate witnesses, deduce the culprit, arrest the culprit, and then go out for donuts. There's chase scenes and shooting sections for the more action-y crowd but these sections have the option to be skipped which is great for people who aren't really good at those or just hate doing them. There are detective games with crimes to solve but none have the depth of L. A. Noire as far as quantity, quality, and continuity between cases.  Each mission takes less than an hour to start and solve depending on how determined you are to find every clue so no case will have you stuck forever. There's also the option to just drive around and solve street crimes for you more free-roaming mission grabbing junkies. There is no failure for messing up an interrogation because there will always be a way that leads to the right convition so you don't have to look up walk-throughs for exactly what to say and find unless of course you want a perfect score.  The real satisfaction comes the very first time you nail an interrogation on the first try and slap someone behind bars. Your boss tell you 'good work Phelps' and your partner says 'nice job rookie' but it feels like they are saying it to you and you feel like you accomplished something on your own. One case down, 41 to go.

LA Noire is a strange game, in that it is a combination of 4 action games (car chase, foot chase, fist fight, gun fight) and an adventure-y detective game that is focused around interrogations. Since all these elements are woven around the same story, it really works, at first. After about five or six cases, it loses its luster somewhat. The foot chases, gun fights, and fist fights are too easy. The car chases are easy too as long as you remap your keyboard so that you are driving with two hands. The interrogations are HARD. Even if I read all your evidence carefully, and review your conversation log, and look carefully at the expressions of the suspect, I still get the answer wrong almost half the time. When you get an answer wrong, you often miss out on evidence that is necessary for later interrogations. So once you start bad, things just go downhill. The case always 'solves itself' at the end no matter how bad you screw up the interrogations, and it does this in a very confusing way. It is very frustrating because you can tell you have missed out on half the story. I have replayed some of the cases using a walkthrough, and found out there were big chunks of the story that I completely missed because I botched the interrogations. I replayed a few cases hoping that I could learn to do better on the interrogations, but it hasn't helped yet. The concept of the detective part of the game is very cool, but in the end too difficult and frustrating. The action part of the game is a little too easy and a little too repetitive. The graphics are very good, the facial detail, the period music and details are great, clearly a AAA game in terms of production values. It seems like this game went straight from concept to game, without any play-testing to calibrate the gameplay to a level where it is challenging but still fun.

This game drags on like a re-run of the hit 1950s show Dragnet, starring Jack Web, but without the fun breaks found in commercials. The player directs, and I don't mean anything by the term, a tough but fair cop through a simple set of investigations which eventually end in a car chase, a shoot out, or a beat down. You might win or lose any of these, but it doesn't really matter. The point is to wade through countless sidebars and cutscenes until all of the boxes are checked and you get a new suit. Pretty much all there is in L.A. Snore is a bad map of Los Angeles, some fairly poor car choices, and traffic and pedestrians that repeat endlessly and do not add to the story at all, and a hard-nosed dead-pan straighter that straight WASP cop who is not likable in the least. I suggest you think carefully about buying this and then don't anyway, it will be more fun.  I paid $7.49 for this waste of time and money.  Pluses: It seemed to work occasionally. Negatives: It seemed to work occasionally. Took several minutes to load, when it loaded at all. Had a lot of cut scenes which gave a back story to a character who I already know too much about. There are no alternate pathes to success. Succeeding is not worth it.

L.A. Noire is Rockstar's anti-GTA game. In Grand Theft Auto, you're in an open world littered with missions, side quests, collectibles and more. There's activities and the insanity that it's famous for. L.A. Noire is it's antithesis. Instead of playing a criminal, you play a detective, solving cases in Traffic, Vice, Homicide and Arson. You're in an open world with very limited additional things to do outside of the very linear narrative.  As a story, it's great, each case is interesting and a challenge when it comes to detective work and though repetitive, it gets truly interesting in the last quarter of the game.  If you do play it, don't make the mistake I made by marathoning it out in long play sessions. Take your time and play it case by case and leave it to play something else inbetween. The gameplay gets repetitive and drawn out and can't be appreciated fully when you're going for >1hour play sessions.

This is a hidden gem of a game. Not only are the facial expressions amazing, but the storyline, and sequences as you advance the game, very well put together. As always, there are things that can be improved, but this did not diminish my enjoyment and suspense. You play a rookie cop that moves along the ranks and various divisions of the police force, as you begin to solve (perfectly and sometimes not so perfectly) crimes of varying degrees. The music adds suspense, tension and lends atmosphere to dramatic scenes. There is a certain realistic feel to the characters and animation, as well as the layout of the game. The controls for the most part are simple and easy to learn. The use of an accessible notebook adds flavour and is really helpful in remembering clues. The puzzles range from easy to pay-close-attention, but generally don't distract from the flow of the story. Depending on your system, the graphics are decent and flow well. My wow-factor is in the facial contorsions and mannerisms, which capture the moods of characters quite well. It is unfortunate that a sequel or a continuation of the genre won't be possible, given that the studio that started this is, as far as I know, now gone, but I recommend this game to those who enjoy noir detective films and books. It still has the feeling of a game, not a novel, but in this one you get to take part and your actions will have consequences. I will certainly recommend it if it is on sale and it should make a nice gift if your intended victim enjoys games with detective storylines.

Simply put, LA Noire is a steaming pile.  Somewhere along the way developing the impressive technology, art direction and amazing facial animation, LA Noire forgot that first and foremost, a game must be fun to play.   The one thing that I absolutely can not stand about the game is the sluggish controls. Even when walking around as Phelps, I feel like I'm driving a tank. Attempting to finesse my avatar to examine a piece of evidence in a crime scene is an exercise in frustration. When not driving the tank that is my character, I'm driving around in cars that feel just as unresponsive, except that I'm required to chase another vehicle in crowded streets. The only section worse than the driving and investigating is surely the shooting. The developers must have known these sections were terrible, because after you fail a number of times, you are given to option to skip the action sequence.   LA Noire is not without some redeeming qualities. The crime scene investigation (when you're not fighting the controls) is very interesting and the interrogations are definitely the golden nuggets amongst the pile of dirt.   However, this concept sounds familiar... Isn't there another game with these fantastic game mechanics, except without the cumbersome mess of action sequences? That's right, it's called Pheonix Wright: Ace Attorney.  If you're looking for crime scene investigation and perp busting action, look no further than Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney!  On a side note, my heart goes out the to development team that produced the amazing art and technology for LA Noire. It must be devastating to work so hard on a title only to have it crippled by terrible game design and then losing your job because the management of Rockstar Bondi is as incompetent as the design decisions.  Worst game I played in 2012.

Overall, I reccomend the game for the price if you can find it on sale for £5 or less. It is a really long game and the entire charm and unique-ness of the game wears off a few hours in. Personally, I find myself too stupid to be able to solve some of the later cases and it didn't help that by that point I just wanted the game to end. The game, at least for me, got rather dull about 15 hours in which is roughly around the 1/3 - halfway point in the game. The only reason I carried on with the game was because I heard that the story towards the end start's getting really good. But 10 hours later I was more bored than I could be and I just decided I couldn't be bothered to finish it. So I watched the ending on YouTube.   The game is pretty much a detective game where you have to walk around crime scenes to find clues and then interview people for information. On the interviews you have to ask questions and then you get the choice to say whether they are telling the truth, to doubt what they are saying or to show evidence (from the clues you found at the crime scenes) that they are lying. You determine whether they are telling the truth or not by how they react. The game used clever face scanning technology to scan people's faces and movements so they look realistic which, while cool, does look a little strange, isn't the best quality and also is the reason the game is locked to 30fps on the PC with no simple way to unlock it. Also, for someone who suffer's from minor autism, I personally have a hard time reading the people's faces to tell whether they are lying or not! You also have shooting and driving sections, but these are rather generic and get dull fast. The shooting sections are fun but are always really short and thankfully the driving sections can be skippable (hold down the button you use to enter the car and your partner will drive instead of you).   The game is fun at first. The first few levels in the game are great fun and you feel very clever. However the game starts to get rather confusing and difficult towards the end and the games charm does slowly start to fade so I never finished the game. However I bought the game on sale and I have enjoyed my time with it. However I never finished it and I am done with it. But I don't feel like I was ripped off so I still reccomend the game.  P.S. L.A. Noire is made by the studio that made every Grand Theft Auto game, Red Dead Redemption, and so forth. It uses a very nifty facial rendering technology which really gives the characters a lifelike look - as they are all based off real actors. The game itself handles much like a Grand Theft Auto game, you play as Cole Phelps a LAPD detective who solves various overarching cases. You'll drive to crime scenes, look at evidence, interview witnesses, chase suspects, get into shootouts, you name it... It's very polished and cool, all the dialogue is voice-acted by real actors. This is not a typical Grand Theft Auto game about shooting people and causing mayhem though, you are really there to look through evidence and solve crimes - shooting bad guys is somewhat secondary to that. I would definitely recommend this game if you're a fan of hip crime novels and big-budget Rockstar games.

Well, I don't know why I'm reviewing this thing when it's 3 years old but I feel like I need to.  It's amazing. It's like the developers saw the CSI games and just went... 'We could totally do it better,' and they did.   The city is beautifully reconstructed and is like walking through a digital museum of the 1950s. I have played through this game 3 times (on the 360) and saw that the Complete Edition was cheap on PC and had to buy it. The extra cases are very good.  The PC version is decent enough. I use a Widescreen fixer so that the game is forced to play in 60fps instead of 30fps as the 30fps caused motion sickness for me. I reckon they should have had more graphical options but really, when your immersed in the story trying to crack a case... you really don't notice the graphical quality.  I enjoy using a 360 controller as the keyboard and mouse just feels unresponsive and if you want that vibration feature whilst looking at clues then you'll need one. It was what drove me into buying a wired controller and a wireless reciever thingy for my 2 wireless controllers. It improves the gameplay by 150%.  I don't really know what else to say. The game is impressive, the cases are great, you can get very immersed in the world and sometimes I end up empathising with a lot of the characters because the emotions on the models faces are just so well done. When I see a victim crying it does make me feel for them and when some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gives me a smug look during an interview I want strangle them.  I find it has a lot of replay value but then again, that might be just me.  50/10 - Please buy this.

This is a different and fun kind of game. You do a lot of interviewing of suspects, investigating crime scenes, driving from place to place in the LA area. It's interspersed with bits of more action-y type activities, like car chases or gunfights with bad guys. There's also optional emergency calls that come through where you can go stop some petty criminal in action. The interviews were really my favorite part; trying to pick the right interrogation technique, when to mention certain pieces of evidence and so on, was fun to do.  There were some less awesome parts of the game. They designed this huge city for you to drive around in, but you can't enter ANY of the buildings except the police stations and whatever building is active for your current quest. It kind of left me feeling cold and disconnected from the city - I couldn't just wander around in and out of shops and houses.   Also (SPOILER ALERT!!!) you end up finishing the game as a completely different character. It was frankly a little odd. I got very attached to the main character, then 2/3 of the way through, you start playing as someone else - who was, throughout most of the game, kind of an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that you worked against. Having to suddenly play as him really annoyed me.   But even so, I still consider this a fun game worth at least one playthrough.

The gameplay is rather smooth and enveloping, sucking you in to figure out who has killed this man, and why. The graphics are above average for the time it was made, from the poignant facial structure, enamoring city of L.A., to the fine scratches upon personal items. The interrogations are vexing and require a lot of thought, especially during the 2nd half of the game. All around, great game, even the second time through. Recommend

In a city riddled with crime and lies you are one of the few who seek truth and justice. As you climb your way up the promotion ladder in the LAPD you must tactfully determine who is lying and who is telling the truth to solve the case. YOu play as detective Cole Phelps, starting out as a regular cop on patrol you are promoted to detective and other departments of the police force. The graphics on this game are one of a kind, using special effects to map the characters faces to look like actual faces and you may even recognize some faces from well known TV actors. This game is set in the late 40's and it a city where you will shoot down criminals, get involved in mob wars, and you'll never find a woman that wears her hair down...for some reason...like ever...it's wierd...literally every woman you meet will have her hair up in a bun...  This game is one of a kind, a classic brought on by Rockstar games. Usually known for their GTA series where you play the criminal causing chaos in the underground they have changed things up with this game where you play the law, and you will feel the pressure as you hunt down murderers and drug dealers. It is vital that you find the clues and squeeze information out of suspects during interviews or you may not solve the case at all which changes the overall direction of the game.   I definitley recommend getting this game, it is a great story and great gameplay.   Overall I give this game 9 out of 10 Toast for Twenty's.

The main meatyness of the game is the interrogation scenes in which you go though a list of questions and listen to the reply's in which case you can say that the suspect/eyewitness is telling the truth, lying or unsure. Get it correct and the mission is made a bit easer for you, get it wrong and you might find the mission a bit more difficult.  I played this alongside Max Payne 3 which I found a better game for storytelling and gameplay. LA Noire will suit you if you like spending ages looking for things and fancy facial technology.  6/10

Also, working on 4 different desks is really cool since you get to see the different branches of the police and what they work with. All in all, I thought it was a really good game and worth the purchase if you are into solving crimes and a good story.

L.A Noire is another gem made by the legendary Rockstar. The story follows Cole Phelps, a detective from L.A who's routinely solving crimes and getting promoted while on the job. He'll encounter many scandals about the LAPD and people question his background and sometimes even hates him for being the survivor of World War 2 on his squad. This game features case solvings, and use motion face recongition to help you determine if they are telling the truth, if you think you have doubt its the truth, or they are outright lying. There's not that much variety of weapons, but in this era of the 40's you'll see common weapons from the era, such as the Tommy Gun and the Colt M1911. The player will get to examine evidence and the crime scene it self. Cole Phelps is also sharp on his style of clothing. I'll have to say my favorite suit would be the 'noob suit' 'The Golden Boy'. This game also carries a wide amount of vehicles and all of them are also from the 1940's era. Overall, the game is extraordinary and has a rich story and wide amount of gameplay. The graphics are amazing and the motion face recongition is very fine. The only thing that bothers me, it's that it's not really an acutal detective game, as it's all following one story and scripted. We should have been able to choose our own paths and that would have made this a what I would like to call an 'IGN Masterpiece 10/10'. My rating for this would be a 9.5/10.

Really liked this title.  First thoughts were that this game has a fairly unique system. Sort of something for everyone here. The game's system allows for someone who wants to play seriously to do so but also allows for someone who wants to just blow through as fast as possible to do just that. I really loved looking for clues, posing questions backed by evidence, and uncovering plots in cases, some of which are clever stylized recreations of actual cases from the time period.  Interesting story lines converge in a pretty well written overall story and feels pretty good when all is said and done. Play time is even better than most 3a titles anymore, at around 35 hours.  The game is set in 1947 L.A. and I loved the fact that when you got in a car you could hear radio brodacasts from stock footage from the time. The Jack Benny Show, old news broadcasts, and of course music from the 40's. The cast of characters is pretty massive and there are a lot of recogniseable faces and voices. Commercial actors, and T.V. and Movies actors alike, not just voices but whole guest apperances. pretty cool I thought. Also cool was the fact that vehicles are real vehicles, Hudson, Chevrolet, Ford, Packard etc.   You spend a lot of the game performing interviews to get along in cases and you have to pay attention to people's faces and voices to get an impression of truth or lies. The result is a really incredible looking facial animation set. It's like actually seeing people talk, no choppy dubbed looking animatronic movements. The only complaint in this subject is that the voice acting isn't always very good. gets a little campy here and there.  The game is gritty and covers a lot of situations. Marital problems, drug use, mental health, corruption, political standings etc.   Definately a Rockstar title, lots of shooting and language but I felt it fit pretty much every situation so it didn't detract from game play except for some of the street crimes ( optional side missions)  All in all I'd say get this and play it if you're looking for something cerebral and engaging. If you just want a run and gun though you're not going to like L.A Noire

resume L.A. Noire quickly, it's the story of a LAPD cop named Cole Phelps and his rise & fall in the police system, all while questioning a bunch of people about various crimes. This game manages to immerse you into the past, in the late 40's as a LA police officer trying to climb the ladder.  I like alot of things about this game: The ambience, the music, the facial system, the captivating storyline, the relevance of almost everything placed in the decor, the dialogue, etc, and the list goes on. Rockstar/Team Bondi (R.I.P.) have done an amazing job on this game, making sure to create a different feel than in their previous games (such as Bully or GTA). There is no other game like this one, and that's a quality I love when it comes to good games.  The story will run you at the very minimum at least 26 hours (DLC included) and you can then retry past cases individually to try and get better. I like to play through L.A. Noire about once every 1/1,5 years (it's kinda like a movie, where it's as enjoyable as the first time once you let some time pass and come back to it).  I would recommend getting the complete edition of this game to any fan of Noire TV series or movies, and fans of well scripted detective games. DO NOT come into L.A. Noire expecting exactly the same as GTA but as a cop in the 40's because you will be very dissapointed. That being said, the game is amazing, probably the most immersive game i've played.

This is a fun game, but you really need a good system to run it, It's pretty large and wouldn't run on my computer when I first bought it, got a laptop with a better graphics card and now it does fine. I love the old cars and stealing them and such, though trying to remember which ones you've unlocked and which you haven't on sight alone gets kinda hard. The cases are good, pretty gruesome some of them. But overall I've liked the game. I did not like the storyline of the main character, why couldn't he just be a good guy cop who gets falsely accused of stuff and proves his way back into glory idk, he's kindof a lil ♥♥♥♥ (but I guess it's dudes back then, although even the guys who beat women are like dude wow you suck), but it's still a fun game to play and pretend to be a detective. I'd say it's worth buying on sale and checking it out if you have the right stuff to run it.

A good game, although not really my cup of tea.  Pro: - nice noir atmosphere (music, design, clothes, cars, scrapbook interface, etc) - excellent facial expressions (for the time). They sometimes feel strange (uncanny valley?) but a geek can't not admire the technological achievements here. - great dialogs and voice acting - it feels great hunting for clues and using them wisely - interrogations are interesting  Con: - it's a GTA-derived game (same engine), but having the whole town is pointless. You just drive between fixed locations, which your partner can do as well. - cars feel not so different and unrealistic; there is no point in driving anything but your police car - again the GTA heritage: controls are not really well suited for clue finding - no saving, so you can't redo certain parts you failed without replaying the whole case (episode if you will). You can still retry the action scenes if you fail those, but not the interrogations for example. - unskippable cutscenes - the story is progressing slowly and is too linear for my taste and age (you are not given much choice, at least until I played - didn't finish it)
Almost 6 years later and still I feel like this game paved it own way and being its own type of game. Definitely worth picking it up when on sale.
if you want a game that makes you choose your decisions wisely this is the game for you and becaues its just fun all around.

Instant and genuine classic. Chasing down crooks, looking for clues, questioning them, using evidence against them, but a few good bashes at old fashion 1940's shootouts, really good.  Only problems were getting it to start, many people have issues, took a lot of skulking through forums to make it work on my PC. Logic of what answers to give Ie, after asking a suspect a question you can either 1)truth 2)doubt 3) lie. It is sometimes 'puzzle game logic,' in that the correct choice is not only not obvious, but not logical. Sometimes when you select doubt, you basically say.... 'are you sure' yet other times you outright accuse them of murder. And sometimes I can anaswer doubt, doubt, truth for 3 questions, all three responces are about the same ... 'are you sure, you should tell me more,' yet I was correct... not a point in the games favour when I can be correct or incorrect and not quite understand why.  These two issues aside, this game has a genuine quality to it and the story is very compelling. 25 hours of game play for me, still some extras to go through, highly recommended.

L.A. Noire is an open world story oriented detective game, to describe it shortly, set in 1947. You play as Cole Phelps, a detective from the LAPD; during the course of the game, you solve different cases as you are promoted between different desks such as traffic, homicide etc. During the game, you are aided by your partner (which is a different detective for each desk).  The cases are very interesting and have stories which only last for one case or even several cases, which will tie together in the end (for example the homicide desk). The game is very heavily story-oriented and besides the cases, it tells a very suspenseful story of Cole Phelps' division fighting in the Pacific theatre of war in WW2 and his comrades, how they adjusted after the war, and how Cole discovers corruption and connections with gangsters deeply within the LAPD.  The gameplay is focused on exploration, as you need to search for clues at various crime scenes to piece together the big picture. A very innovative and still amazing feature is the motion capture technology used in this game which renders facial expressions with astonishing detail. This is needed, because you need to interrogate witnesses who may or may not withhold information from you - you need to deduct if a person is lying (using evidence to prove it) or not telling the entire truth. Your partner may sometimes be able to suggest places to try next to advance the case.  The city, Los Angeles, is beautifully rendered and captures the film noir atmosphere perfectly. Because the game focuses on the story, the city is mostly used as a backdrop - there are no activities outside of a couple of side missions called street crimes. These are usually short but very exciting missions. There are quite a lot of beautiful cars you can drive, although the driving isn't anything special (the feeling is mostly similar to GTA San Andreas).  The story is quite long but very engaging and will keep you glued to the seat until the end!  Summary  Pros:  - Excellent story - Authentic film noir atmosphere of 1947 Los Angeles - the city, the cars, the music - just perfect - Unique gameplay features - collecting clues, interrogating suspects/witnesses - Extremely detailed facial expressions  Neutral: - Driving mechanics  - Shooting mechanics  Cons: - Occasional stuttering even on high end machines - frame rate locked to 30 fps (but otherwise playable)  Overall: If you are a fan of such games (I recommend Mafia 1 and 2 for a similar feeling) this game is excellent!
It plays like an old movie. It even has a bunch of well known actors in it. And if you really want a Noire film sort of feel, you can switch it to black and white.

The game is set in post war California at the boom of the film industry and organised crime, following the detective Cole Phelps as he moves up in the ranks of the police department. The game has references to locations, films, cars and cases from the actual period but never really took full advantage of the period or the police perspective. The period however was well replicated for the game and the open world is pretty much flawless.  The game itself revolves around point and click investigations of crime scenes and interrogations using the truth/doubt/lie reaction system in combination with the suspect's/witness' reactions. The investigation then develops based on the amount of evidence found and correct interrogation options chosen. However choosing the wrong options or missing evidence will result in you missing out sections of the case as you are not prompted to visit key areas or talk to key people. This can be a problem as the doubt/lie options in interrogations seems to be inconsistent, and evidence needed for the lie option is quite often circumstantial.   The story focuses on the character of Cole Phelps who has returned from fighting in Japan to take up a position in the California Police Department. Phelps is a straight policeman with a cool head and quickly rises through the ranks as he continually produces results. The story is generally generic and dull as Cole Phelps is such a reserved character and outside of the cases there is minimal story. The cases however are, for the most part, interesting and varied.   Pro's:

I LOVE THIS GAME SO MUCH. So many feels because the plot is so good. The cases are all great, though I feel the game is best played slowly, not all at once. It can get tedious (especially the driving) if you try to play through it all at once. Lots of side quests (street crimes, film reels, rare cars, etc) and fun achievements. This is one of my favorite games of all time.  That being said, I hate the Rockstar 'Social Club' crap that they force you to use with the game. It has to update basically every time I play and I don't even use whatever 'features' it provides to the game. Obviously not interested in being social if I'm playing a singleplayer, plot-heavy game...
